details.description: The rules for working on Sundays, opt in, opt out arrangements, rules for shop and betting shop workers, special arrangements during the Olympics
details.body:
Having to work on a Sunday depends on a person’s employment contract - and there are special rules for shop workers and people who work in betting.

You should check either:

  • the employment contract
  • the written statement of terms and conditions

If it doesn’t mention Sunday working, a person can’t be made to work - unless both they and their employer agree and put it in writing (eg change the contract).

Sunday working in shops and betting shops

Staff don’t have to work on Sundays if they’re:

  • shop workers who started before 26 August 1994 and are still with the same employer (in Northern Ireland, this is before 4 December 1997)
  • betting shop workers who started before 2 January 1995 and are still with the same employer (in Northern Ireland, this is before 26 February 2004)

All staff should be told about their Sunday working rights when they first start work.

Opting out of Sunday working

All other shop workers and betting shop workers can opt out of Sunday working by giving 3 months’ notice.

An employer needing staff to work on Sundays must tell them in writing that they can opt out. They must do this within 2 months of the person starting work - if they don’t, only one month’s notice is needed to opt out.

Staff can opt in to Sunday working, but mustn’t be treated unfairly if they opt out.

Employers only have to pay staff extra for working on Sundays if it’s in their contract.

In Northern Ireland, employers must also give any shop and betting staff who work on Sundays written details of how they can opt out.
